text: 0.65l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. Only my cat like reflexes saved this from fountain ingen over the table. No gusher, but wants out and it has a massive really good looking near fluffy everlasting off-white head. All this on top of a cloudy deep orangey warm body. Looks nice and smells really nice as well. Lots of malty and fruity nuances. Hard to describe this aroma. Its almost yeast nutty with a rush of red berries and sweet melon. Yeah, wish every enn could smell like this. This is tasty. Super car smelly and somewhat sweet all this without being too much. Its spot on the carbonation and it has a fantastic feeling in the mouth as well. Lots of ripe fruity touches with minerally rocks and earth. There is lots of wet rocks and even a little bit of spicy licorice here. So much flavor! My expectations were quite low before popping the cap on this, but wow. This is one amazing esb. 23.10.2013

Deep, super hazy brown and toffee coloured body with a great, three centimetre tall light brown head that looks nice and tops the beer even better. Aroma of toasted malt, toffee, earth, grain, rye, german/english hops and a bit of alcohol - rather pungent in the nose. Medium-bodied; Very earthy and toffee-y flavours up front with a lot of toasted malt, grain, rye and english hops with some sugars and a lot of alcohol noticeable. Aftertaste shows the grain and earth more than anything else, but the lighter alpha acid hops show through along with the earthy sugars and a touch of fruit. Overall, a decent ESB with some good qualities, but nothing too impressive or out of the ordinary. Definitely not a must-have beer or worth spending a lot on - but nice to finally sample. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from King Richards Wine & Liqour in Michigan City, Indiana on 09-September-2015 for US$8,99 sampled at home in Washington on 30-August-2016.

Floral hops, earl grey tea, wet straw, very bittersweet orange, marmalade. Hazy gold, small, creamy, off-white head. Medium bitter. More earl grey tea, pine, floral hops, light sweet grain and bread malts coming up, caramel, soft carbonation, light bitter and dry finish. Nice ESB, quite intense Earl Grey flavours, niche, floral bitters. Bottle from Discount Liquor, Milwaukee.

Tap at Dexters. Filtered caramel amber-brown body. Off-white pillowy head. Nice tropical hop notes over classic British ESB caramel amber notes. Pretty good, medium bodied, not so much malt depth. Kind of bright and awkward for the style. OK.

Average frothy, off-white head. Clear orange to copper colored body. Aromas of lightly toasted bread. Some green hops and licorice as well as a hint of cooked corn. Lightly sweet throughout. Flavors of corn, herbs and wintergreen. 6/10
A really good ESB. More hops than I typically like in an ESB, but the pineyness is pretty appealing. Nice, caramel backbone. Picked up in Chicago in 2016.

Clear reddish mahogany, white head. Light brown sugar, grain. Some light biscuity notes. Grass. Quite bitter, a good bit of sweetness. Medium body, some light oiliness, an amount of acidity, some carbonation. Some alcohol. Quite good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Cloudy amber color, with an off white head. Grain, caramel, malty, kind of bitter, stale bread, sweetness, and some grass clippings. Meh ok.
Bottle shared at a tasting. Dark orange pour, hazy, thin tan head. Smells like malt sugars and burnt caramel. The taste is bitter-sweet, with notes of malt sugars, citrus hops, some pine.

Slightly hazy amber color with beige head. Aroma is floral with caramel malts. Taste follows with caramel, some fruity esters and hops, finishes on the bitter side. Medium body and carbonation. Really nice and easy drinking.
Cloudy brownish amber pour with a soft white head. Nose is salted caramel, raisin, pine/resin hops. Medium mouthfeel. Resinous hop with a sweet and salty malt backdrop. Tasty ESB.
Nicely done. Pours golden orange with an off-white head. Aroma is full of sweet malt. Medium bodied, nice English base. Light hop finish.

Bottle sent as part of a surprise box from starcross -- thanks a ton, Clint! This beer tastes a lot like the image on the bottle. Its got a British base, but taken to an extreme level, just like the mecha-Horatio Nelson on the label. Tons of malt flavor with a lot of clove and fruits, and a good amount of hop bitterness at the end to balance it out. A good (just not at all traditional) American ESB.
Pours amber with a off white head. Aroma is pine, citrus with some caramel in the background. Taste is caramel, citrus, apricot, and pine.

BOD 9/24/15. Clear amber pour with a slight garnet cast. World class head volume, lacing and retention.

Rather light but nice nose of citrus (orange), a touch of spruce spiciness, tea and grainy biscuit with a bit of caramel.

Light medium body that is smooth with a touch of oiliness. Normal carbonation with a bit of effervescence in the middle and a stronger burst in the finish.

Quite nice flavor profile, but not quite up to snuff compared to the outstanding classic English bitters, such as Fullers (which is world class). Hop flavors present are predominately tea, whilst light citrus floats around a bit. The rich heavily caramel background is a bit out of balance lending the bitterness to not cut and slash in a sharp crisp fashion characteristic of the style. Do a side by side with Fullers ESB and youll taste what Im saying. The middle bitterness is a bit muted for the style and does add apricot flavor, as advertised. The finish is a slow sweet fade. This beer is quite nice and very flavorful. As a pale ale I would score it outstanding, but as an ESB - it misses the mark.

Hazy dark caramel with big, frothy, beige head, decent lacing / Bright nose of citrus, pine, sugar / Light to medium body, sweet, hoppy but not overly so, balanced, light bitterness on finish / Muted, lightly cooked flavors of spun sugar, grapefruit, apricot, pine, toast / Solid, maybe not one of the better from 3F.

Bottle thanks to Deyholla. Reddish pour with a small white head. Spruce. Spicy hoppiness. Caramel. Red apple. Flavor of orange peel and spruce. Fairly hoppy. Dry spicy finish. Chewy malt. Toast. Pretty active carb. Basically a hoppy Amber. Fine for what it is.

22 oz bottle. Pours ruby red murky with a sticky thick head. Aroma of sweet hoppy caramel. Initial taste of malty caramel. Thin mouth feel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

22 oz bottle shared by ebone1988. The pour is a deep ruby mahogany color
With a nice off white head that fades to a film and thicker collar, leaving some good lace behind. The aroma is very fruity. There is a lot of apricot and juiciness to accompany a lightly bitter malt on the back end. It's not really the bitter I was expecting, but it's different... Kind of like everything Three Floyds does. Not necessarily a good thing. The flavor is interesting. There is a little bittering to the malt that happens on the back end that reminds me of an unsweetened tea. It's got a decent flavor and a light bittering to it. It's sweet up front and then slowly over through a lightly bitter finish. It's not bad. Not that great. The mouth feel is a little viscous and lightly carbonated with a lingering sweet malt backed up by a light bitter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is a nice sweet malt, juicy hops, candy sugar, bitter. Appearance is dark amber, a very light tan head. Taste is malt bomb, a bit of hops, a lot of tea flavors, some orange peel, pretty good. Mouthfeel is medium body and carbonation. Overall, one of the best ESBs out there.

Pours copper with a decent white head; not much lacing present. Aromas of citrus, apricot, and piney hops with notes of caramel maltiness and stone fruits. Taste is more subtle; caramel, biscuit, some raisin/plum notes, little if any apricot present in the taste. Not my favorite 3F offering but for an ESB style its quite good.
Bottle pour amber copper with moderate ecru head. Nose sweet fruit, dried apricot, caramel malt. Taste moderate bitter bite up front, dank hop, caramel malt. Light bitter finish.

Bottle from Big Red Liquor, Indianapolis. Pours a dark, murky amber body with a fingernail of white head. Enticing hops aroma of caramel, perfume, and flowers. Flavors continue with more resinous hops, pine, grass, biscuit, malty caramel. Finishes dry with subtle bitterness. Lively carbonation and medium/full body. Good brew.
Aroma is complex tropical fruit and light hops. The flavor is tropical fruit, fruit, hops/mild hop resin, malts and a bitter/very slightly tart finish.
Hazy amber color out of the bomber with a nice rocky beige head. Toast and marmalade nose. Nice toasted malt and toffee sweetness with some orange marmalade and apricot jam flavor. Tasty ESB.

Now known as Lord rear admiral. Dark brown with some amber hues. Big foamy off white head. Nice balanced malty aroma with some sugar notes. Not getting much hop. But it is an easy drinking complex malty beer. Would definitely drink again

A good beer. Pours a dark Amber with a creamy, off white head. The aroma is pretty subdued with subtle malt. Flavors of toasted grains and malty sweetness. Nice finish of fruity hops. Very balanced and drinkable.

October 28, 2015 - bottle from Liquor Locker. Nice looking pour with some white fluffy head that lasted for a bit. Aroma was strong with the fruity hops, but also had some sweet malt. Sweet malt and toffee dominated the taste initially, but then a dark fruit came through before finishing with the fruity bitterness. Like the historical reference and have wanted to try this as a result for a while. Not sure the connection with this beer as I would have thought a barrel aged brandy beer would have been more appropriate given Lord Nelsons body was preserved in brandy when transported back to England.

エクストラビ  
甘い、苦味と&

On tap at World of Beer, Wauwatosa, WI. Brownish-orange pour with a creamy khaki head. Mildly sweet aroma but honestly not much comes through in the aroma. The taste is malt-forward with toasted graham cracker and biscuits with just enough hop presence to keep it from being too sweet and cloying. Nice beer for whati s typically a boring style.

Bomber from brewpub dated 9/23/15. Pours a deep red amber with nice retaining head. Nose of rich, sweet, toasty toffee malt, bread, and a hint of juicy hops. Flavor is hoppy stone fruits and light foliage with a nice warm roasted malt structure. Substantial mouthfeel. If this were more frequent around my area, it would be a great go-to. Good stuff for sure.

(draft @ Sergios World Beers - Louisville, KY) Orange pour with a thin white head. Mild malt aroma with a hint of sweetness, but I couldnt tell it was apricot. Flavor is bready and malty with a mild hop finish. Slightly fruity. [9/10/15]
UPDATED: OCT 8, 2015 Told this was the best esb in the country at the brew pub. Took home a bottle and i agree.
Bottle. One of the better ESBs I have had for shizzle. Good, subtle citrus notes. Solid beer. Superspak has unfortunately not rated this beer yet.
Bomber poured medium hazy amber with a huge foamy head and lacing. Aromas of fig, citrus, apricot, and biscuit. Medium bitter flavor. Very nice ESB.

Deep amber with a great big frothy off-white head. Description sums it up perfectly, complex malty and apricot hoppiness. Why rehash? Some floral. Medium body. Mild to moderate clean bitterness. A good example of FFF at its best. Good balance, well rounded, interesting, full of flavor. I certainly wouldnt mind this as a regular option. Top quality and really well-made and enjoyable.

Strong apricot, bitters, hops taste and aroma. Smooth, high quality taste without any unpleasant bitterness at the end...though there is a considerable amount of bitterness throughout the middle end of the taste.

22oz bottle in a taster glass. Pours amber with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of pale and caramel malts, some floral hops, and light dough and hints of spices. Flavor the same with a nice blend. Average texture. Not a bad beer but not my favorite style.
Burnt orange pour with semi-creamy white froth. Sweet malts, apricot/stone fruit notes, orange marmalade, soft carbonation, full mouthfeel, perfect amount of bitterness. Very tasty version of an ESB.
Dark amber with a medium head. Aroma of marmalade. Solid apricot, marmalade, and buttered brown bread flavor. Moderate bitterness. Full body. Delicious.

Burnt orange color, slightly cloudy. Huge off white head. Aroma has some citrus notes that are almost apricot like. Medium mouth. Taste is full of apricots, almost earth-like. Bitter, but not dry. Interesting flavor profile. A little lace hangs around.

Pours a hazy amber color with a fluffy foam head that laces my glass. The aroma is of sweet malted grains, fruit, and a light herbal floral hop presence. Tasting, I noticed a sugary grain flavor, dryness from the soft booze, a minor apricot taste, some citrus, and a pleasant bitterness. Overall the finish is enjoyable and this was a kind drinker. Id have this again.

Bomber from Jims in Mundelein. Hazy amber brown pour with an off-white head leaving some spots of lace. Aroma has malts, tangy pine, light stone fruits and some earth. Taste is of sweet toffee, pine, some citrus and some resin. Medium to full bodied with some alcohol. Finishes sweetly tangy with some bitterness. A bit more hoppy than many bitters, although not as much as one expects/hopes for from a FFF product. 13.6

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange color. Aroma is sweet malt, fruit and malty sugar. Flavor is clay, sweet earth, flour and caramel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber thanks to respertFTW. Cloudy chestnut with a beige head. Mild, tropical hops and dry.

Poured a caramel amber color with aromas of citrus, caramel, light ginger and some makt. Flavors are mare light citrus and apricots with makt and caramel light bitter and ginger spiciness in the aftertaste.
Surprisingly apricot/citrus aroma as well as strong caramel. Taste is of caramel, candied orange, and some bitter pine.

Look - Dark orange. Medium off white head, almost tan. Creamy head. Lacing. See through.

Smell - Caramel. Bread. Light fruitiness. 

Taste - Caramel. Bread. Grassy. Orange. Lemon. Apricot. Raisin.

Feel - Medium body. Doesnt explode. Taste of some wheat beers without the carbonation. 

Overall - Not a taste I have often. Nice change of pace from the stouts and IPAs in the collection.

22 ounce bottle labeled as Lord Rear Admiral, bottled on 03/20/2015. Served in a pint glass, the beer pours an amber/copper color with about an inch off-white head that stuck around for a long time. Theres also a good amount of lacing. Aroma is nice, the brew smells like caramel and bready malt, stone fruit, and some grassy hops. It tastes like caramel and bready malt, toffee, candied oranges, grassy hops, and some apricot and light citrusy hops. Good balance between the malt and hops. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit coating with a moderate amount of carbonation. Its also smooth and easy enough to drink. I wouldnt exactly call this a traditional ESB, but I sure liked it! $9.99 a bomber.
enjoyed this in my hotel. pouts amber with a slim off white head. stone fruit, light sweetness, light flowers. light to medium body with a lingering finish.

Bottle, purchased at the brewery and shared with Parksy. Hazy amber orange, lasting off white head. Sweet caramel malts, soft peachy hops, big flavour. Delicious.

text: On tap at Bangers & Lace. Pours a reddish amber colour, clear, with a frothy white head. Aroma is of bready malts and some citrus hops, though not too pronounced. Taste is malty and mildly sweet with a nice bitter undertone. Medium body, softer carbonation, and smooth and creamy on the palate. Overall a great and unique ESB.

Pours a clear, darker amber in color with a full white head that settles very slowly. The aroma is malty. Its bready, with toffee, herbal hops, vanilla, and hints of orange. The taste still leans towards malty, although there are some fruits and hops. Toffee, cherry, orange, bread, grassy hops, and some spice. It tastes kind of like fruit juice actually. The aftertaste is cherry and seems to linger for awhile. Light to medium in body, it has a slick texture, and has an average level in carbonation. I find this very easy to drink. It goes down well. This one is different with what it offers. Id get it again.
this is an esb? youve got to be kidding me. hey, floyds, stop tinkering with classic beer styles. this beer makes no sense.

Really just a stunning ESB. Nose is malty, rich, a little hops note, and very enticing. Pours a "dirty" amber, on the darker side, with orange tinge and nice very light tan head. Flavor is a moment of malty sweetness followed by a rush of dryer hoppiness, Very well constructed, tasty, and drinkable.

Enjoyed on tap at Emporium Arcade Bar in Chicago, IL on a day off, too bad it's cold and grey. Appearance is a moderately clear Amber with a modest white head that laces to the glass. Aroma has a hop abundant profile with light malty notes. Taste is unique, definitely bitter with a bit of lemon, some off flavor that isn't quite agreeing with me, but malty as well. It's ok, not especially feeling this one.
Pours clear amber with hefty beige head that sticks around. Aroma is sweet malt, very nice and fresh. Taste is very sweet and malty as promised. Love this domestic ESB!
Bottle shared with Dave, GOT S5E1 Beer 2. Pours amber. A bit more hop forward than most ESB. Hints of fruit. Nice.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, dark reddish pour with white head, aroma brought nice notes of pine, grass, citrus into a bit of orange peel, some mango, slight pineapple into some earhty, spicy notes, touch of yeast. Taste was a mix of earth, grain, citrus, and lots of mango, caramel into a bit of pine, slight yeasty notes, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, floral hops, & fruit; Flavor of malt/biscuit, caramel, floral/fruity hops, and citrus; Finish is fairly bitter; Nicely balanced. Good one.

Draft to taster. Looks good for the style; a transparent caramel orange with foamy off-white head. Smells mild; what scent there is though is of bitter hops and caramel malt. Tastes like it smells, but hoppier, and with a bit of a juicy hop presence alongside the bitter hoops as well. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied. Not bad, and tastes more robust than it smells.

Dark red/Amber pour with an off white head. Lovely lime and caramel aroma. Bitter but not aggressive, the lime/citrus is suttle but lingers on. Good balance here, nothing off here. This is a wonderful beer. I was hoping it was lower in abv though, wouldnt mind sitting down to 5 or 6 pints of this. Certainly not much in common with an ESB but thankfully ratebeer doesnt rate by style.
650ml bottle. Amber pour. This is extremely boozy and hoppy for an esb yet right in the abv guidelines. Not a good esb.

Bomber (label clearly says Lord REAR Admiral BTW... although this is supposedly thats the name of the alias but I digress...) Pours a hazy burnt orange, huge, frothy off-white head with ridiculous retention and lacing. Nose is big toffee malt, orange candy, vanilla, honey. Mouth is medium bodied, relatively dry and big orange zest, clover, floral wallop at the finish, a whole lotta underpinning bitterness throughout, Dont know really think this tastes anything like any authentically English ESB Ive ever had... and at any rate, as Winston Churchill said, their naval tradition amounts mainly to rum, sodomy and the lash... but this Admiral is a solid beverage regardless of where you wanna classify it. Even if the Floyd bastards made it.

From bomber. Pours an almost clear red with a big foamy white head and lost of lacing. Aroma is stone fruits, biscuit, and caramel. Taste is at first bitter with soft hints of fruits and caramel. This beer is not sweet, but the bitterness mellows as it warms. Quick and slightly bitter finish.

Esb/amber? Not my thing. But this beer is. Red pour from draft, clear with a little white head. At State and lake. Fruity Cherry aroma. Taste is also fruity and a little tropical punch hint, with a bitter finish. Really good
First bitter! aroma of bready maltiness, some hops, taste is hoppy, fruity, apricot, guava, aftertaste is short.
Pours dark brown with a big head. Has a pretty good flavor. Descent but not great.

Bottle: (Labeled as Lord Rear Admiral....3-19-15)
Pours slightly hazy amber with a thick beige head.
Spicy apricot, orange....herbal hop aroma.
Flavour is herbal bitter, light fruits, caramel malt, hay/grass.
Really enjoyable....a very nice, hopped-up bitter.

22 oz. bottle shared by Dan P, thanks bud! Fresh bottle without question here. Hazy amber orange color with lasting head in the pint glass. Aroma is a large amount of citrus and herbal hops on top of a toffee and caramel base. The flavor is just as aggressively hopped as the nose.
Flavor starts bready and toffee malty and transitions into the aggressive hop finish. The bitterness is of medium strength and balanced with the sweet malts. Highly drinkable and very easy for me to session this. If this was more available to me I would buy this as a go-to brew. Could be the best ESB I have ever sampled (mainly because it is an over-hopped American version of the style) well crafted.
ivory white head that disappears with lacing. amber colour. aroma of dill, pickels. taste malt, dille with slight bitter finish. medium body and carbonation.  bottle 75 cl

Thnx to belgbeergeek 
Pours fuzzy orange , big white foam 
Smells sweet , hoppy 
Taste is bitter , rather hoppy . Sweet , ok

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 23.10.2013, 0,65l bottle sampled @ BBGTC tasting:
Small creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly sweet fruity, light malts, sugar, grain, dried fruits, butterscotch, almond milk, grass, old leafs. Taste is slightly sweet, light malts, harsh hay, sugar, grain, weeds, almonds, butterscotch. Medium bitterness, slightly dry and harsh mouthfeel. Nice for being a not too fresh bottle.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Pours a hazy deep copper-hued orange body with a massive creamy off-white head. Nose is floral piney tones, biscuits, red fruits, hints of fruity caramel and white sugar. Taste is red fruits, pine, herbs, mellow caramel, hints of biscuits and toffee. Amazing fruitiness and very nice balance, Medium body and carbonation. What a great American-style ESB! Hats of to Three Floyds for this one. :-)

Very lively. Pours a orange cloudy body with a gigantic white head. Light caramel and malts on the nose with toffee and light grassy notes. Taste is well balanced with malty caramel, toffee and a light, floral bitterness. Hints of melon and citrus. A superb and highly drinkable ale. Crisp mouthfeel with semi-dry finish.

Amber/dunkel, opaltrüb, weisse schaumkrone, wunderbar süsslich fruchtig im aroma, antrunk süss caramelig, sehr gut mit bittere ausgewogen, sehr schön anhaltentender abgang/nachklang, mittlere rezenz

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bomber into a 3F pint glass.
Clear golden brew with a beige head that laces nicely down the glass.
Grassy hop scent. Smelling apricot? a tad of caramel?
Hop first then the malty sweetness. Finish is telling me ESB
slightly above average

Rated on 01-30-2010 - This beer pours a medium sized smooth ivory head with good retention, good amount of lacing, visible carbonation, and a golden hue. The Aroma is malt, caramel, sweet, and citrus hops. The Taste is fruity, citrus hops, malt, and caramel. The Palate of this beer is fairly smooth. Overall, this is a very quaffable beer and worth trying.

Bottle shared with Travlr at Churckey; I cannot recall if it was from their collection. Aroma of toffee/caramel, almonds and moderate resin. Appearance is translucent copper with bone head. Flavor matches the nose; very mellow, and quite nutty. Palate is light, sticky and soft. Very nice.

Pours copper in color with a medium off white head. The aroma is floral, citrus, grapefruit, and some caramel. The taste is floral and citrus hops with a solid caramel malt backbone. Medium bitterness on the finish. I like it.

Pour is light brown with a slight red tint and a finger-wide head that lasts for a while. Aroma is of rye grains, cloves, slight hop bitterness. Flavor is balanced nicely and starts off malty but transitions into bitter/dry. Notes of apricot, caramel, bready malts, citrus hops. Creamy mouth-feel, good.
22 oz bomber from 3 floyds. Pours deep amber with a small off white head. Floral and citrus aroma. Peach caramel and hop taste.

New batch.  Lord Rear.  Had this last year but remember it being quite different.  Although the last year i did sit on it for a while.  Orange copper pour.  Very hop agressive.  Lots of citrius and apricot, the signature 3 floyds hop.  But this is really out of place in this ESB.  Lots of carmel malt that you would find in a bitter.  But doesnt blend well.  I dont remember it having these hops last time.
copper color, aroma of toast, earthy notes, grass hops, same flavors, very good ESB

Bottle. Pours dark ruby with a big white head. Nose isn't as strong as I'd like, but it's complex with lots of earthy hops, citrus and caramel. Deep caramel malt takes center stage in the taste, supported again by piney and citrusy hops. Great soft palate with a lively carb. Very nice ESB. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz. bottle purchased fresh from the brewery. This beer is atrociously poundable. Pours a beautiful clear copper with a frothy white head. Nose and flavor bring lovely earthen loam, fresh spicy green hop, touches of rye and beautiful bready malt balance. So nicely put together, and gorgeous, drinkable palate. An impressive American ESB interpretation.
i wonder what the tweaks were. went nicely with the pepperoni, rosemary red sauce, giardinera, pork belly, mozzarella, and goat cheese pizza. on tap @ brewpub. rating #1!
bottle. amber with two finger head. nice hoppy ESB. hops are definitely english-style. pretty easy drinker.
Wish I took more notes apart from: Creamy, hoppy nose. Light medium body, just good! I recall it was.. obviously enjoyed too much to detail..

On tap at St. Bock.  Pours a clearish amber colour with modest-sized white-ish head.  Aroma is earthy hops and caramel malts.  Flavour is very richly malty with toffee and fruit as well as a nice earthy hoppiness.  Average body.  Moderate bitterness in finish.  Pleasant.

Sample at Ale Wine & Spirits in Powell on 07/20/2012. Pours a cloudy iced tea color with a medium off-white head that recedes steadily. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of biscuit malt, hops and fruit. Medium-bodied with flavors of caramel malt, ripe fruit, piney hops and a little spice. The finish is malty with an earthy and fruity aftertaste. Good ESB all around.

Bottle, shared at Midsummernights beer tasting.
A bit hazy, amber body, large offwhite head. Aroma is very hoppy; grass, flowers, with a good malt backend. Complex yet balanced taste of biscuits, pine, grapefruit and tea. Ends bitter with taste of pepper.

7th July 2010Hazy deep amber beer. Frothy white head. Slightly soft palate. Lovely fresh hops. Sweet pineapple, marmalade orange - slightly bitter, pine. All on a decent malt base. A very English name and if all English bitters tasted like this you would never get me out of the pub!
22oz bottle from 3F, This is a confusing beer, as strong bitter could be used as a weak IPA to me, and this one smells great but is more attenuated and subdued, strange for 3F

75cl bottle at An ipa tasting.
Thin white head.  Hazy amber pour.  Lovely fresh bitterness. Yummy.

Refrigerated bomber from csteele2144 poured into a shaker.  Pours clear copper with finger and a half off-white fluffy head.  Little lacing, medium body, low carbonation, and caramel malt and hop aroma.  Taste is caramel malt, spicy grapefruit, hint of pine, and nice bitter finish.  Leans toward an IPA, I would love to try this back to back with Fullers ESB.  Three Floyds has produced another great beer.

Another great three Floyd's. Pours a dark copper from a bomber. Very smooth and easy going. Big fan of this English bitters. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Extra in a trade from Darkobs...thanks!  Slighty cloudy brown.  Persistent head.  Caramel malts on the nose.  Sweet caramel malts with nice hop balance.  Full, round palate.  Nice, very drinkable and smooth.  Not very complex but solid.  Much sweeter and fuller than a traditional English ESB.

22oz bottle I picked up at DLD 2012. Porued a relatively clear copper-brown color with a foamy medium-to-large sized white head. Aroma was toasted malts, almost like fresh grains on brew day - really enjoyed that moment I opened the beer. The flavor is a bit middle of the road - but to be expected - sweet toasted malts, bitterness.

Auction winner. Sampled with Steogsaurus. Another great beer by 3F.

A great blend of caramel malts, pine, sweetness and toast. Very good for the style.

Bomber. Brownish copper pour with a decent non lasting head.  Nose was pleasant with plenty of hops and other floral and spice notes.  Taste has a very familiar FFF hop forward presence along with a solid malt backbone.  Enjoyable different approach to this style.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650ml bottle. Muddy orange with lots of slightly orange head. Webs of lace. Black tea leaves, grapefruit and spice on the nose with something else I cant put a finger on. Black tea dominates the palate as well with a big spicy vibe. Finishes very dry.

big head, highly carbonated and has a muddy orange/amber colour. aroma is very hoppy, spicy and has  a black tea component that is interesting. Big flavourful brew with lots of carbonation, has an alcoholic kick and bitter. very tasty!

Cloudy bronze pour, big fruity aroma, thick head with great lacing.  This is a flavorful bitter that gets better with every sip.  Another outstanding beer from Three Floyds.

Muddy orange with a fragmented head. Strong tropical aroma of peach,  pineapple and orange. The flavour is initially sweet but quickly turns into a dry bitterness. The finish is long and a bit aggresive in its warming alcohol, despite the relatively moderate 6,5 %

Bottle, courtesy me. Pour is light brown/amber with a beige head, good retention/lace. Aroma of citrus, pine, apple, biscuit, very light toast. Taste is biscuit, orange, resinous hops, light tea. Palate is oily, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Very good.

651mL thanks to tastybeer. No thanks to tjthresh. Pours a tea amber with a rocky, sheen, yellowish head. Sheety, sticky lace. Nose is soapy, stickier orange moving to excellent cinnamon apple pie. Pours a cloudy medium brown color with a fluffy cream colored head. The scent lives up to its name as it has a strong bitter scent of hops. Good citrus flavors, grapefruit primarily. Nicely bittered, Hints of liquorice and black cherry. Sweetness and caramel of a double IPA.

2012 vintage poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a seidel

Pours copper in color with a medium off white head.  The aroma is floral, citrus, grapefruit, and some caramel.  The taste is floral and citrus hops  with a solid caramel malt backbone.  Medium bitterness on the finish.  I like it.
Bottle. Golden-orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma is grapefruit, floral, hop, malt. Flavour is grapefruit, peaches, floral, hop, malt. Full bodied nice beer.

Admiral Nelson pours a nice copper color.  One finger head with a ton of lacing. 

Words cannot describe how in love I was with the aroma of this beer.  If every ESB was like this it would easily turn into one of my favorite styles.  Its a hoppy ESB.  Floral and piney. Like I said, I just found my favorite ESB.  Grapefruit and citrus steal the show here.  The lemon comes in next with a nice kick of herbal spice notes.  Caramel malt background with a smell but nice lingering bitterness.  Sweet and bitter at the same time.  Wow.  Full of flavor.

Light black coloured. Has an off-white head, mostly lasting. Aroma of sugars, citrus, pine. Flavor is starting moderate sweet and finishing moderate bitter. Dry, creamy texture. Some good notes, some not so good.

Pours hazy and gold with a small white head. Nose is caramel, pine and English malts. Taste is sweet with some great hop balance. Mouthfeel is creamy in the front sharp in the end. Great esb.
