light hoppy aroma,amber,hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, light soft hoppy finish.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle via trade.  It pours a light amber color with a nice off white head.  Good head retention and lacing left behind.  The nose is a mix of toasted malt, caramel, and slightly earthy hops.  The flavor on the malt side carries from the nose with a bit of graham cracker.  Along with the earthiness, I get a bit of pine from the hops.  Smooth with softer than average carbonation and a short to medium finish.  This is a good daily drinker in my book and worth having should you find it.
Clear golden color with fine head. Nice spicy aroma and flavor. Lots of citrus and pines and some anise.
Bottle. Hazy golden with medium tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, fruit, hops and citrus. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit, peach, pine, hops, little citrus and medium bitter.
Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Average moderate bitter flavor. Average finish. Creamy palate.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is hazy dark amber. Aroma and taste are rich malt, fruits, caramel, nuts and hops.

Bomber from the brewpub. Pours a hazy amber color with tiny suspended particles. Large frothy head. Good head retention. Aroma of fresh leafy hops, earthy notes and toasted malts. The taste is citrus hops, some leafiness, caramel and toasted malts. Medium bodied. Very drinkable.
22 ounce bottle.  Pours a hazy amber with a large fluffy biege head.  Aroma of caramel malt, pine and citrus hops.  Taste is similar.  Somewhat bitter finish.  Smooth.  Very nice.
Poured from 22oz bottle.  Pours a murky red with loads of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is citrus hops and just a bit toasted malts.  Taste follows the nose with a fair amount of bittering hops.

Bottle at Beer Temple.  Slightly cloudy golden pour with small white head.  Citrus hops with biscuit in aroma. Flavour brings in some caramel and fruit.  Carbonation seems a little high but still a great example of the style

In short: An explosion of juicy leafy hops over tasty cookies.  Excellent IPA-ish beer
How: Bottle 22oz, consumed fresh 3 weeks after purchase from brewpub.  Split three-way, thanks to the Trois-Rivières kidder garden
The look: Partly cloudy dark golden topped by a very small beige head
In long: Nose is bursting with fresh leafy hops over fresh cookies.  Taste has a lot of cookies, toasted crusty bread, smooth caramel and of course lots and lots of fresh leafy hops that sometimes get into citrusy territory.  The bitterness is of medium intensity and the finish is clean and a bit dry.  A beer to be consumed uber-fresh.  This beer is especially fun because uber-hoppy beers rarely have that hop bill.  Im sure there were American hops also in there but overall it felt different than most American IPAs.  A bit reminiscent of a lower gravity version of Three Floyds own BlackHeart.  Named after an English naval war hero who bravely fought the French before the French had perfected the art of quickly surrendering.
Yeah THIS is a bitter! Reddish pour, off white head.  Great citrus hops, caramel, honey, stone fruit in the nose. Flavor is such a perfect harmony of malt and hops...loved it.

Take notes England this is how an ESB should be done!  The charming intricacies of the style are paid close attention to and then hopped with an amazing  blend of hops to get a great flavorful beer.  Couldnt get enough of this one.  Citrusy hops accent the lightly sweet malty body that you would expect from an ESB.

Best bitter Ive had. Great hoppy aroma, mostly floral and some citrus. Then the malt bill of a delicate bitter. It shines through the hops perfectly. Tasted like the malts from Selins Grove bitter but hopped like an american IPA. Another laser show from three floyds.

Fresh 22 oz from brewpub.  Deep red.  Fresh citrus/herbal hops, caramel, meaty fruit, and biscuits.  Very even citrus hop flavor, orange and lemon zest, toasted/roasted malts, and at the end a touch of caramel sweetness.  Citrus holds to the palate along with mild sweetness.

Bomber. Amber with half inch off-white head. Aroma is caramel and hops--not really piney or citrusy. Flavor is caramel and a little citrus. Long dry finish. Perhaps my taste buds are off but this is tasting very similar to Alpha King (more so than I recalled). Nice ESB.

Bottle.Pours golden with an creamy off-white head. Aroma of woody hops, floral notes, malt and fruitiness.Flavor is sweet and bitter with some grassy and herbal hops.Medium body, average carbonation.Well made ale.
Draft at brewery. Pours golden orange with aromas of peach and other fruits along with a sweet biscuit nose. Really nice. Flavors of caramel, pine, butter biscuits. Easy booze finish.

Bottle shared in Glouglouburps hotel room @ soirée des brasseurs. Copper pour with white head. Powerful aroma of fresh leafy hops, something a little floral and fruity too, almost pears. Hoppy flavor, peppery, english ale yeast, very IPA-like, boosted flavor. Palate is nice and dry, good bitter hop finish. Completely exaggerated, out of style and excellent - Three Floyds style.

Tap at the brewpub.  Aroma: biscuity, toasty malts, caramel, mellow floral/spicy hop character.  Pours a hazy amber, white head with average retention, thin lacing.  Flavor: toasty malts, caramel, fairly high alcohol for the style, firm bitterness and floral hops.  Medium body and carbonation.
I love this. Malty and full flavored. Perfect flavor with a roasty flavor. Pours dark and nice head. Wonderful body.

On tap at the brewery.  Pours a clear orange-red with a thick white head.  Aroma of lots of fruits (apple, pear, citrus), jam, and sweet malt.  Flavor is very sweet with more fruits, jam, and citrusy hops in the finish.  Plenty of pale malts too.  Nice ESB.
7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]
Sampled this one at the brewpub. The color was straight ahead gold. Medium to light in body. Balance of some light malt and understated bitter hops. Not too lengthy in its finish. Not bad.

Split bomber with sherm1016....thanks to nephew Pat!!  Dark amber color with thin head....hoppy nose and taste...not overpowering but excellent bitter flavor.  Pat...you can come back anytime...bring more FFF!  A very fine beer.

22oz bottle split with dwm1034.  Pours a copper color with a thin white head and some lacing.  Aroma is mild, hoppy. Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is bitter, with a nice balance of malt and hops.  Not the best from FFF, but a nice beer own its own.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2011 Draught at FFF?  Aroma is bitter, but balanced. Pours a nice light brown with minimal tan head. Taste is malty on the front end, then the fuggles kick in to provide some nice balance.  Overall, a very, very good bitter that is as balaned as any a bitter I have had..   Very well done.

Pours a hazy orange with a soapy, fast dissapating head.  Aroma is peach, mango, toast, yeast, and a hint of clove. Taste is rich fruity malt with citrusy and slightly vinuous finish (no doubt from the use of nelson sauvin hops!). Body is medium, slick, low carbonation and a dry finish. This bottle is brewery fresh and ihas tons of yeast still---live ale in the bottle! Fantastic.  The closest you can get to a beer engine experience in a bottle.

old notes.  Got a bottle of this at a trip to three floyds.  this was my first ESB ever.  Pours a merky orangy yellow with a small white head. smell is yeasty citrus hoppyness. The flavor is nicely balanced between yeast and hops.  It was a goot beer not too bitter like what I was expecting.  Im still unclear about the ESB title though, must have more.
Hazy orange colour with a small off white head. An aroma of semi dried grass, bread, spice and weak bread. A flavour of grass, spice, citrus, flour, grain and spice.

Pours unclear orange with not øuch head. Aroma is somewhat hoppy, citrus, lemon zest, english yeast, very fruity and nice, some maltiness to. Taste is all the same, nice fruity, citrusy, nice bitterness. Not your classic ESB.

Hazy amber with a lasting off-white head. Aroms is sweet, malty, caramel and moderate hoppy - fruity. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and bitter finish. Most breweries would call this their IPA. 140511

Vollmundiger Hopfenantrunk mit süß blumigen Noten. Diese festigen sich im Mittelteil, in dem das Bier zudem herb wird. Das vorhandene Malz unterliegt dem Hopfen so deutlich, dass es kaum auffällt. Auch später ist der Hopfen angenehm blumig, bleibt aber der Intensität eines amerikanischen IPAs deutlich zurück  es ist wirklich die amerikanische Version eines Bitters, auch wenn das Original deutlich alkoholärmer und geschmacklich entsprechend schwächer ausfällt. Super Bier! 6/11/11/12/14/12

A very big foamy head on a good looking beer. First taste is sticky, hoppy,  (thats good) and the second taste is yeast and alcohol (thats bad). The taste is more Belgian pale ale, than esb, but it is not a bad beer. But it gets boring before you have finished it. On the other hand, Im not a big fan of caramelmalt (I think thats it) or english hops (Fuggles). This one gets my "average-ESB-grade" and I had expected more from Three Floyds. It´s not even very well balanced.

I havent had a lot of experience rating ESBs as a style, but this seemed like an American Pale Ale. Piney and citrus notes and flavor. I did pick up notes of sweet caramel malt. Great hop flavor. Nice caramel color and good frothy head with lacing.
I would not have guessed the 6.5% ABV. none detected at all.

Hazy orange body, small white head. Aroma of fruits and yeast, cookie dough with raisins, alcohol. Quite odd. Flavour adds some roasted, malty yeasty and bready notes. Some vainilla. Resiny and booze. Woody. Not balanced.

Bottle thanks to Alex, served in a Bells tulip...Is this the beer that gets me to like esbs? Its easily the best esb Ive had, maybe thats because its more of an ipa...A medium copper, good retention and lacing...Super smooth aroma of caramel malt, light grass, hops have a nice light bite. Taste is essentially the same, super easy to drink with a caramel base, and just enough hops to make it enjoyable and not boring to drink. 

Another great 3f that should be sought out.

Amiraali Nelson on oranssi ja samea. Vaahto on kohtalaisen runsas ja valkoinen. Tuoksultaan olut on simamainen, siirappinen, rusinainen, hedelmäinen ja hieman mäntyisen pihkainen. Maku on rusinaninen, katkera ja mäntypihkainen. Tuoksussa ja maussa on on myös hunajaa. Eksoottisen hedelmäinen ja pehmeä olut. Virkistävä.
Golden, unclear. Aroma: Grapefruit and apricots, malty profile and a good dose of hops. Same elements in the taste. Long bitter aftertaste, good lively carbonation. Nice little acid underneath.

I feel like there is a pine hops to it, but thats because I just had an Alba pine ale. Anyway this one was everything it should be. Orange haze and Medium bodied with the right amount of hops to still be refreshing. I liked it.

650 ml bottle. From København, Denmark.
Murky light brown colour with small off-white head.
Aroma: strong maltiness combined with yeast, caramel and not-so-fresh fruity hops.
Flavour: bitter hops, heavy maltiness, some alcohol and notes of fruitiness. 
Too malty and heavy to be true to traditional English ESB.
Bitterness stays in aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, deep amber with a big, creamy off-white head. Good lacing. Great aroma; citrus and pine hops in a perfect blend, with a candy sweetness to boot. Not very complex, but simple and just plain great. Full-bodied flavour; heavy on the citrus and pine hops with a good dosage of fruity sweetness, without becoming cloying. Remote notes of liquorice. Malt in the background peeks out as it warms. Bitter hop finish with a lingering grassy note. The bitterness isnt overdone, but is nicely balanced. Too much carbonation. Overall a really good beer, with the carbonation being the only thing thats off. 06.03.11.

Bottle 650ml at 1337 beer#5 courtesy of Zoney. Pours hazy light copper with offwhite head. Aroma is citrus, grass, fruits. Taste is light sweet, medium bitter. Light to medium body, thin to oily, average carbonation. 26022011

Bottle 650ml @ 1337 Beer #5
[Courtesy of Zoney] Pours cloudy amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of grassy, fruity hops and caramel. Taste is light sweet and medium bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 Pours amber with an off white head, Aroma of hops, pine, and lighter sour fruits. Taste is hoppy with pine, grapefruit, malts, lemon peel, mandarin - leading to a dry bitter end.

Big thanks to Eric for his generosity...this poured golden with amber highlights.  The noble hops and bready malts were both noticeable in the aroma and taste.  Well balanced. One of the better ESBs that I have had the pleasure of tasting.

Another nice bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a clear copper hue with a medium white head. A nice nose of fresh fruity hops, some biscuit and light fruit. A lovely flavor of hops, medium bitterness, noticeable though, but balanced out by a nice biscuit-like malt, not overly strong or simplistic, a great ESB.
Great Beer! Taste slighty bitter with a citrus floral flavor.. Very smooth and natural.

Bottle, bought @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph.
Pours lovely amber with a big, staying, creamy, white head. Great duration. Aroma has lots of flowery, slightly red apple-y hops, light grapefruit and pine. A firm caramel malty base with some doughy characters. Low carbonation, fairly light and quite dry mouthfeel. Flavour is elegantly hoppy, some caramel, doughy and light biscuity malts. Piney, light fruity hops. Long, lingering, heavy bitterness. Very nice and very drinkable.
Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours copper with a foamy beige head. Strong citrus hop aroma. Med body. Very floral in the mouth. ESB on steroids. Long floral bitter finish. Enjoyed this immensely.
Bottle from the brewery. Pours cloudy amber with a modest beige head and a floral aroma. There is a delicious caramel malt flavor with a smooth bitter finish. Very tasty.

Pours a substantial cloudy amber with two fingers of creamy ofwhite head. Nose shows an appropriate level of diacetyl and notes of citrus zest, pine, and herbal hops. Flavor is zesty and piny with some bready notes. Palate shows a medium bitterness and body. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a hazy and dark amber beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness and hops with citrus. The flavor is close to the nose with some additional caramel. The palate is bitterness and some sweetness. Overall a good beer.

From notes 03/2009. Enjoyed on tap at FFF on St. Patricks Day 2010. 

...my backbone is shot through. 

A bright fulvous beer, the color of Horatio Nelsons badges Im sure, with a somewhat disappointing half-finger head and lacing.

I came into this one blind, and Ill leave it blind, but the nose is full of an overwhelming array tropical fruit hoppiness. I dont know the style well, but this particular beer is strong and bitter, as the style suggests. A sharp mango, citrusy hoppiness meets with a minor bready malt backbone. Grapefruit rind, resin, orange. 

Creamy, but a bit thin, though highly drinkable. I drink a third of the Admiral, wonder if I can finish the glass after a few other FFF beers, and all of a sudden, Nelson is dead. He is gone, but he has gone bravely. Unsurprisingly, this is an excellent beer.
A nice tasting ESB with a little more hop kick than usual.  As usual strong flavors are present with any fff beer as well as a smooth and heavy mouthfeel.
12 oz bottle. Pours a nice amber with slight, off-white head. Strong hoppy aroma with ripe citrus evident. Taste is riipened orange with grassy notes. Another nice offering from 3Floyds!

Bottle.  Sweet apricot/orange malt and light grass/grapefruit hops aroma.  Cloudy amber color with moderate head.  Slightly sweet light toffee malt and moderately bitter green grass/citrus hops finish.  Nice body.  Excellent.

nice pour, gardually hazier and hazier until its totally cloudy. nice head is creamy and leaves lots of spotting. giggity! the smell is  a lot of sweet biscuity malts with hints of caramel, with a  dry hoppy backbone, if that makes any sense. the tadte is similar, malts upfront, hops in the end. prett nice actually, may be a nice gateway beer to get american strong ale heads into the more english style bitters. ???
Botle @ Odense tasting. Amber body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is hops, fruit, pine, grape fruit and some caramel notes. Flavor is hops, grape fruit, pine and caramel. Medium carbonation.

22oz bottle. Deep amber with a big off white head. Aroma is typical 3Fs citrus hops (its a good thing) fruity/floral and sweet caramel.  Flavor is caramel malt, citrus hops, a little fruit, floral, grass. Creamy sticky mouth feel.

Pours a rich copper color with a huge fluffy light tan head.  Intensely citrus aroma (grapefruit and orange?) with some hop notes.  Oranges are immediately apparent which fade into a slight bitterness.  Some sharpness from the carbonation with a syrupy texture, and a fading bitterness.  Tasted like sort of like hoppy orange juice (which isnt as bad as it sounds), but I feel that it needs more bitterness to be a better representation of the style.  In general, I really enjoyed this beer.
Pours cloudy copper with a beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, citrus, grapefruit and peach. Flavour is caramel, citrus and peach. Medium bitter. More american than english.

1 pt 6 fl oz bottle shared by larsga. Low blond head. Bronze colored body. Peacy and citrussy hop aroma with a floral note. Dry malts in the background. Taste is a nice and balanced mix of slightly sweet and light caramelized malts vs a peacy and citrussy hop flavor.  A good bitterness throughout.  Medium body. Dry and fresh in the mouth. Utterly drinkable, good quenching abilities.

Bottle @ Odense Tasting, December 2010. Pours hazy orange with a small creamy white head and lacings. Peach, caramel, yeast and bread. Smooth and filling body. Dry and hoppy flavor - citrus and peach. Excellent!
65cl, exclusive American brew, thx to Jeppe!, complex brew, slightly bitter, yet refreshing, balanced, hazy, small head, good brew, but expensive!

Light hazy golden with a white film that leaves a good lacing. Inviting aroma with apricots, peaches, malts, dried fruits and hay present. Alcohol, sweetness along with hoppy acidity and bitterness that follows through into the dry finish. Syrupy texture, medium to full body.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 On tap at the FFF Brewpub in November 2009.

Poured a dark copper with a nice creamy head, although not as much as is normal for the style. The nose is definitely dominated by some great citrus hops atop semi-sweet caramel malt. The taste was very similar to an IPA, but with a decidedly English influence, though still different from an English IPA. Medium body with good carbonation, the drinkability on this was excellent, and Im really looking forward to being able to try the bottled edition.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 01-23-2010

Bottle. Pours a nice cloudy orange color with a small and frothy white head. Aroma is of hops, grapefruit, citrus, sweet, bready and caramel malts and some toffee. Flavor is nice jucy hops with flavors of citrus, white grapes, grapefruit, herbs with a tea like taste, sweet candy type maltiness, caramel and toffee, bready and biscuity malts. The body is medium with a nice silky smooth mouthfeel. Overall a really good ESB, with an American twist to it.

Bottle from crown in indy.  Pours a deep red/amber with a nice tan fluffy head. Head diminishes quickly. Leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is of lighly sweet fruity dry hops. Flavor is all sweet hops with sublte notes of caramel and fruit. Medium creamy body with a lightly bitter finish.

Dark amber, thick creamy head. Light orange, soap and citrus. Orange candy, cookie, thick and robust body, very chewy with sugars. Would have worked better as an IPA, definitely needed balance here with some pale malt.

Small yellowish beige head. Amber body. Milky resiny papery aroma with malty honey straw notes. Dry floral caramelly papery taste with resiny strawy notes. Mid-bodied. Dry roasty peachy wooden alcohol aftertaste with grassy strawy lingering notes. Nice and highly drinkable. (0.65l bottle, Ølbutikken, Copenhagen.)
(bottle) deep amber with off white head. Malty aroma. Flavor is biscuit malt, some floral/citrus hops

What a great easy drinker!  This beer has little after taste for an ESB.  Smokey and malty, flavor comes through after the swallow.  Almost a peanut note.  Thick tan head, brownish amber color.  Another great beer from 3 Floyds.

22oz bottle pours a hazy, burnt orange with a frothy, off white head.  Nice aroma of noble hops, citrus rind, earthy.  Flavor is sweet, orange rind, a little soap, caramel, a little cracker.  Medium bodied, soapy finish.  An ESB?  I dont think so, IPA territory for sure.

Bottle at Struise School courtesy of Urbain.  Deep amber colour lasting beige head.  Some fresh curshed amlt aroma.  Yes it has more fresh toasty malt.  Yes some hops.  Yes a bitter.  Just lacks something.  But as an American Session ale its very good.  Could drink a lot of it.  Well 3 pints.  Decent.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with James and Vin. Pours a chestnut turbid brown with a half-finger, bubbly, off-white head. Slight lace. Aroma of hazelnut, caramel, oak, bitter hops, slight vanilla and toffee. Medium bodied with a loose, juicy, oddly boozy palate. Finishes with caramel notes and ginger spice. Very good for its style, but bitters are still not my pint of brew.

Bottle split with and courtesy of Pat. Pours a dark, hazy amber body with nice thin head that lasts throughout the session. Aroma is bitter hop, cinnamon, maple, slight malt. Mouthfeel is slightly dry - hops up front with a malty, woody, nutty backbone. Great ESB, good beer.
22 ounce bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar, thank you.  Golden color, decent malt and hop balance with nice aroma and mild bitterness.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours clear golden with a tiny white head. Aroma of fruity hops. Taste is medium bitter,, lovely fruity hops with traces of spice and caramel. Medium bitter aftertaste.

The best aroma on an ESB I have smelled with a ton of lemon fresh citrus. The ale pours golden and a bit cloudy with a decent amount of sediment and decent bubbly head. The flavor is very zesty from the citrus notes and a nice full body for an ESB, much more flavor than expected.

I only know this is not really a bitter because of my one (not enjoyable) experience with Fullers ESB, just not for taste.  More of an IPA really.  Pours amber gold.  Nice hop aroma.  Hops dominate with malt sharing the stage on the back end.  Too carbonated for my tastes, but that gives it a light mouthfeel.  Enjoyable, but I probably wont repeat.

More of an IPA than a bitter.  Hazy orange brown with a tan head.  Strong hoppy aroma with pine and grass.  Bitter grass flavor with notes of pepper.   Bitterness lasts on the tongue.  A bit astringent.

22 oz. bottle from the brewery.  Pours a clear amber color with a two finger thick cream-colored head.  Aroma of fresh herbal and floral hops, orange citrus, wood, caramel malts, and pineapple.  Flavor of orange citrus, sugar, fresh hops, caramel malts, pineapple, and pine resin.  Light-medium bodied, with a sweet, hoppy mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Definitely not a conventional English-style bitter, but that is probably a big reason I like this one a lot, as Kent hops really arent my thing.  Very cool ESB.
Premium bitter, lol. Big crazy hop nose, lots of citrus, lots of sugary malts. Taste is moderately bitter, lightly sweet, lots of citrus hops, a tad astringent, some honey on the finish. Decent IPA.

Bomber. Pours very lights golden with a thick creamy White head. Aroma is very fresh pungent hops nothing like your typical esb. Still a nice sweet caramel note, a touch of candy sweetness and a fresh citric fruit note. Flavor is very hoppy and sweet lots of fresh fruit typical of three floyds almost to a point of being a lighter alpha king. There is a definite smooth creamy malt in the finish that brings it back towards the esb realm as the bitterness is quite reserved. Medium body and a moderate lightly fizzy carbonation. Interesting American style bitter

Bottle, kindly shared by gunnar. Deep golden colour, moderate white head. Interesting fruity and hoppy aroma, hints of marmalade and oak, some vinous notes too. Hoppy flavour, good bitterness, moderate malty sweetness, hints of oak.

22oz bottle. Pours a clear, pretty amber colored body with a finger-width, dense and foamy, light tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Solid ESB aroma. It has lots of citrusy florals and some piney resins, but a sturdy caramel backing. Some toffee and a light grain with some peaches and herbs. Flavor is similar. Lots of citrusy florals and a much more distinct pine. There is a really nice caramel, toffee, slight grainy malt to balance behind all the typical FFF hops. More peaches and herbs come out at the end as some smooth nutty toffees grow into the finish. Lots of hops with a somewhat sharper resin help dry this out with a medium-high bitterness that leaves a lengthy aftertaste. Medium, creamy body with a moderately lively carbonation. Overall, a solid ESB. Lots of hops and a really nice, smooth toffee-caramel-nut maltiness to balance. A classic FFF take on a fairly standard style.

Cloudy brown pour with an off-white head. Aroma was dominated by the hops, with some nice malty undertones. Flavor was spicy hops balanced with the malt. It was a little dry and left a great bitter and hop aftertaste. Low carbonation made it go down smoothly. Nice lacing. I really enjoyed this beer.

22 oz. bottle via trade with Sean9689 - Pours a clear deep amber color with a one finger thick off white head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is floral hops and resin.  Quite hoppy for a Bitter.  I like it.   Flavor is a nice balance of toasted malt and hops.  Finish is only slightly bitter and doesnt linger.  Medium body.  A very nice beer.  Thanks Jason.
really strong hop presence in the nose. flavor is amazing hops up front decent follow through on the malts but this is a yummy hops show. have drank in bottles and on draft at the pub

Mikkeller Bar, Copenhagen, DK.
Bottled, 031010.
Light amber with white head. Aroma of malt and spicy british hops. Flavor with fruit notes and solid bitterness.

Bottle from the brewpub : Pours a cloudy dark golden with some sediment and an off white head with some nice retention. Aroma is very hoppy,and as the brew warms a bit of sweetness. So, obviously theres a nice shot of bitterness in this brew - Mouthfeel is creamy, but probably on the medium side. Flavors are a nice mixture of heavy english hops, i suppose, with a dry malty backbone, where again there is a bit of sweetness on the finish as it warms in my guiness pint glass. At times I noticed a distinct earthiness as well - Fantastic brew - really, my first brew in this style.

Courtesy of sebletitje. It pours copper with dirty off white head. The aroma has pleasing notes of citrus to pine resin to orange cream sherbet to spicy hops. The taste has firm orange notes, a hint of heavy cream, grapefruit, pine hop resin and some spicy hops followed by a mild earthy note mixing with a touch of malts creating a pleasing and dry black tea sensation to go along with the rest of the flavor.

Pours a cloudy amber/tea color with a thin white head.  Strong aroma of citrus hops with a malt backbone.  Grapefruit, citrus, and grass flavors.  This beer is a very hoppy compared to the average bitter, but still really enjoyable.  Another great original beer from Three Floyds.
Strong hop aroma, resiny. Sticky hop flavor with a strong bitterness. Long lasting finish with a creamy mouthfeel. pleasant.

cuivre, blanche
pas mal de citron se dégage à larôme, en ligne avec le style, léger arôme de malt caramel et de biscuit.
au goût, me rappelle des citron style keylime, beaucoup de note fleurs et pamplemousse, avec encore qcq éléments de malt caramel, le citron et citronnelle reste présent tout au long de la dégustation et ajoute une note légèrement amer.
Pas mal pour un style dont je ne raffole pas trop.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to Urbs and Charles.Very clean golden brown with a good off White head. This is really good. Really good hoppage atop some excellent creamy malt. Well balanced, refined and superbly drinkable once Id decanted it a little. Really good bitter finish. Delicate for an American beer. Really like it.

1pt 6fl oz bottle thanks to Marko, on September 24, 2010Slight bit hazy deep golden color, big lasting light tan head. Hoppy, cream, sweet scent. Also some spices. Bitter, hoppy, sweet taste with the slightest hint of metallic. Fairly bitter aftertaste. Medium low bitterness. Medium mouth feel.

Big bottle courtesy of Mikkel, enormous thanks!Slightly hazy golden-amber body, a little darker than average, big white head that went away at a slow pace. Soft sweet malty nose mixing with peachy notes. Peachy-orangey mostly malty sweet taste, not much bitterness. A little sticky/heavy but not too much. Notes of ice tea. Bit peppery/dusty. A nice soft drinker, thats actually warming.

Hazy amber with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of bread and biscuit, with resinous and grassy hops and a certain note of tea - husky tannins? Malty flavour with orange peel and grassy hops. Bitter finish.
22 OUNCE BOMBER-A copper brown pour -beige head-aroma and taste of caramel, some spice some hoppy notes-somewhat smooth bitter finish-pairs well with spicy food
Bomber courtesy of stfun.  Pours copper with an off white head.  Smells of sage, floral, spicy, spruce.  Tastes of caramel, sage, resiny, sticky, spicy.  Very nice use of hops in this one.

clear orange/brown, smooth offwhite head.
hoppy and bitter aroma, pine, grapefruit.
flavor is bitterhoppy, slightly floral/pine/grapefruit, malty, faint licorice.
appears well balanced and quite solid.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Pours an almost clear amber with an off-white head. Hoppy nose with quite some caramel also. Medium body, very smooth and soft mouthfeel, dry caramel accents and fruit with some late phenols. Dry and hoppy finish. 190710

Pours a medium sized offwhite head with good retention and sticky lacing. Clear amber/orange in color, good lookin brew! Nose is nice, piney, citrusy with caramel malts workin their way in, juicey. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation, slick. Lightly sweet maltiness, toasty at times. Lotsa juicey hop flavors, piney, citrusy with some earthy undertones, light grass and a hint tropical? Well balanced hoppy malty finish, good biterness. Nice one 3 Floyds! Thanks to motortoddhead for the bomber!

Bottle shared by sloth at SL. Pour was very classic ESB-like, full amber to orangey color, nice slightly frothy firm head on top, retention great, lacing good too. The aroma was woodsy and spicey hops over a toffee and caramel base. The flavor followed, some light dried fruits in there too. Mouthfeel was full and aptly carbonated. Very nice, and a thank you to Bert!

Bottled. Pours slightly hazy, amber with a large off-white head. Excellent lacings. Grassy nose with flowers, grass and citrus. Medium sweet flavour with light malts, grass, notes of spice and caramel. More dry and nice, bitter finish. Enjoyable.

Bottle.

Pours hazy amber with a firm beige head.

Dried fruits, passion fruit and red berries. A bit barley wine like.

This draft brew from a beer festival poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized off-white colored bubbles that were and left behind a uncarbonated transparent dark yellow brown colored body. The aroma was cardboard and mild hop. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of mildly bitter cardboard and hops. Not one that I would likely drink again.

Bottle thanks to Rando7. Pours amber with white head. Nose is combination of floral and bitter hops and citrus. Thick caramel malt body. Complexity includes citrus, bitter hops, breads and bark. Dry finish.
Hoppy aroma notes of grass and citrus. The beer is golden, but the flavor is very good again bitter almost an IPA, but it lacks hops to be an IPA.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Aroma of sweetness, caramel, flowers, spice, flavour of flowers, herbs, light fruits, caramel and spice. Medium to full bodied. Dry herbal sweetness in the end.
22 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is fruity and slight flat malty. Dry hoppy, mild citrusy and pinewood. Dry and slight soapy into a dry hoppy and fruity finish.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear medium amber orange color with a average to large, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, citrus - orange, grapefruit, pine, flowers, mandarin notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, mandarin notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100613]

Bottle. Pours orange, semi hazy, white head. Notes of figs and apple in aroma. Add some sesame seeds and hints of whiksey and some burned notes in the aftertaste and you get the taste. Medium bodied. Tastes like a mix of an american barley wine and a pale ale.

The color is hazy bronze and the head is creamy. The aroma has a lot of different citrus-fruits, mostly the orange colored ones, but also clear grapefruit, I also find malt, biscuit and caramel. The flavour is moderately sweet with the same notes of citrus as the aroma, peach, light spruce, biscuit, light caramel and the finish is rather dry with notes of citrus. Its a nice one!!

Bottle. Thanks to Motortoddhead for the hookup! Pours a pale orange without much visual carbonation. Flavor is slightly sweet and toasty, very mild. Has the signature slight sugar sweetness of the 3F beers, which makes them oh so tasty. Finish is dry with a European hop bitterness. Tasty.

Bottled. Amber colour, mediumsized beige head that leaves nice lace. Aroma is fruity and quite grassy along with some wooden notes. Flavour is quite the same in a very dry grassy and bready way. Dries the mouth out with the strong bitterness.

Draft. An unclear amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of English hops, elderflowers, malt, and a bit of caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of spices, caramel, malt, elderflowers, and hops, leading to a bitter finish.

Another 22 oz bottle from beernbourbon. Pours a hazy orange yellow with a small thick white head. Aroma is lemony citrus and herbal hops with some toasty biscuit malt. The flavor starts with lots of biscuit maltiness and the bitterness comes in and leaves you wanting another drink. Medium body with average carbonation and a clean finish. Great full flavored fresh ESB, with that signature 3F flavor. Makes me want to drink more beers of this style.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Hazy orange coloured with a small off-white head.
Fruity aroma of grass, hops and pine needles.
Fruity flavour of caramel, hops, pine needles and grape fruits.
Dry hopppy finish.

22 oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a clear amber color with a small off white head.  The aroma opens with a hefty dose of juicy citrus with a focus on grapefruit and moderate influences of pine.  Moderate sweetness.  The flavor opens hoppy with the grapefruit, citrus and pine in abundance.  The malt is toasted caramel with mild sweetness.  Finish has a nice amount of bitterness.  Medium bodied, somewhat smooth and tasty.

Rating #90 for this beer.

Bottle sharedby coyotehunter. Pour is an orange amber with little head and fruity aromas of peaches, pears and oranges. Flavor is the above with  a grassy bitterness in the finish. Very fruity and sweet for style.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This poured a a brighter amber color with a white head. Aroma was nice piney and grapefruit hops with some underlying caramel notes in there. Flavor was classis caramel and biscut notes from an esb blanketed with those fresh 3F hops. Excellent bitter.

1/28/2010:  Three Floyds Admiral Lord Nelson...  Aroma:  Wow, nice hop aroma - juicy red grapefruit and tangerine with lots of pine.  Appearance:  Clear coppy color; subtle carbonation; off-white to beige-colored head.  Flavor:  Lovely flavor and accompanying bitter; toasty toffee malt with loads of soft pine, grapefruit (red) peel, some sort of orange-colored citru; reminds me of a weaker, more subtle Dreadnaught.  Palate:  Medium; slightly creamy and smooth yet oily; coats nicely.  Overall:  Flavorful and bold; finally, a new offering from Three Floyds that Ive actually enjoyed.
1 pint 6 fl. oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #87 for this beer.

Bottle in Copenhagen, kindly shared by Rune and skinnyviking.
Fruity, full mouth fee. Lots of malt, dry herbal hoppy finish. Cloudy dark gold. Mint, grass. Soft, yet bitter finish.

A big bottle was bought at Ølbutikken and shared with KnutAlbert and Skinnyviking during a drinking session at my hotel room. Beautiful bright copper-golden body. Filmy layer with tiny patches. Fresh aroma of succulent fruity hops. Sappy blended taste of different citrus fruits like lemon and oranges and with malty sweetness beneath. Dry bitter hops to a well rounded ending. Great bitter (Copenhagen, 09.05.2010).

Botella. Deep golden unclear colour. Ripe fruitybit sweet pleasant aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour is fresh and full of ripe fruits, good bitter hoppiness, citrus, pine and caramel. Bitter sweet hoppy fruity well alsting finish. Thanks for sharing this botella Pinball.

Clear amber - offwhite head.
Abricot, fruity. pineapple, grassy, flowery, Toasted, grassy, light malty, nice hoppy, light sweet notes, nice fresh.
22oz bottle. Poured a medium amber color with a small sized off white head. Aromas of floal hops, citrus, pine, and some caramel. Tastes of citrus, toastiness, floral, caramel, and pine.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen.The pour is kobber golden with a moisty glance and frothy white head. The dry hopping is blasting fresh hops out in the aroma. On top of that a clear caramel maltyness, som melon, honey, ginger and lemon-peel. The taste is pretty straight forward, single minded with a nice full bodies bitterness. The finish is long and bitter sweet with a malty base. The tickeling seems to give the impression of more alcohol than there really is. Certainly a good beer.

(22oz bottle, courtesy of thirdeye11)  Pours a clear amber body with a small white head.  Aroma of caramel, pine, herbs, florals, and caramel.  Flavor of caramel, pine, some cocoa, nuts, toffee, and herbs with a bitter finish.
Bottle3. Low fluffy off-white lasting head. Hazy amber body. Honey malt dried fruit aroma and flavor. Long bitter aftertaste.

Lightly hazy dark golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of floral hops, pine, Nelsons, citrus, toasted malts, and some sweeter toffee.  Taste of sweeter toffee up front, citrus, Nelson Sauvin hops, and toasted malts.

Thanks to Josh for sharing this one and letting me keep the bottle to add to my 3F collection.  Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a smaller bubbly off white head.  Aroma of NS hops, grapey, fruity, tea, toffee, nuts and caramel.  Flavor of tea, classic 3Fs yeast profile, grapey and fruity NS hop notes, Sweet malty flavor profile yet still kind of dry mouthfeel.

22oz bottle from Westview. Dodgy label but otherwise a super attractive pour, pale cloudy orange, substantial looking, and an invitingly creamy head. Nose is lightly biscuity, with abundant dry hops looking over the prow towards a different stylistic category. Just a delight to linger in the mouth too, super creamy, like cask beer out of a bottle. Can definitely taste the Fuggles, but the malts are so delicious here, understated enough but suffused throughout so expertly that the beer is really a model of the style.

2010 Bottle - Thanks to the dark benefactor motortoddhead!!!! - Pours a hazy copper with a medium sized beige head...aroma is full of floral hops and roast grain, dry toffee malt, doughy and slightly resinous...flavour is similar, immediate pitchy bitterness, cereal grain, biscuity and incredibly floral in taste as well...finish is clean and lightly bitter, but full of toast...very tasty!!

A: The pour is an amber/copper color with a fluffy off-white head with some sheets of lacing.

S: A very fresh hoppy aroma with lots of grapefruit and pine. The caramel malt provides some nice sweetness as well.

T: Lots of bitter and juicy grapefruit fills the tongue at first. This is followed by a sweet and mildly bready malt flavor with a touch of bitter pine on the finish.

M: The body is medium with a slightly creamy carbonation and feel on the tongue.

D: This is not always my favorite style, but Three Floyds has done well here. A nice hop component which allows a bit of malt to come through, but not all that much in terms of sweetness.

22 oz bottle.  Clear orange brown with a foamy beige head.  Nose is toffee, orange and pine with hints of melon.  Smooth medium body with a mild buzz.  Taste is Mandarin orange, honey, jasmine and grass.  Lingering citrus peel.  Kind of a cross between Dreadnaught and Behemoth.
Light body. Grassy. Hop aroma still there (dont know how fresh this is). Bitterness is dominant. Very nice beer. Not an American ESB, for sure.

Just another great hop juice concoction from 3FsFuggle hops float out in aroma as well as any of their American compatriots,grassy maybe floral in nature,of course dominating ,but lighten up a little. Flavor,light mixture of the grassy hops and backing malt. Would have to be the first beer of the day to keep this mark,would probaly taste even lighter if this were your third or fourth. A light Hop gem

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2015 draft at Indiana Winterfest - Pours amber with an off-white head.  It has a big hop and caramel malt aroma.  The sweet caramel malt and substantial hops are well balanced.  Medium bodied and extremely good.

Ive had this several times, both on tap at FFF and from a bomber.  Usually it starts out caramelly and bitter, warming to reveal the citric hoppiness FFF commonly employs.  That version is very enjoyable, but twice it has not been.  Once from the tap and once from a bottle it has had a slighty offensive grassy aroma and more pronounced grassy taste.  I had thought this was unique to the Admiral, but have recently experienced it with one bottle of Alpha King from a six pack.  Rating based on both experiences, but I would give the good version a 3.8.

Nose is full of hops - pine, citrus, some tropical fruity notes. Caramel, toffee, and some a touch of sugary notes. Pours amber with a nice fluffy head and great sticky lace. Sharp pine and fruity hops up front followed by some caramel malts, light sweetness, toasted dry bread notes, and more fruity hops in the finish. Some lingering resins and bitter notes. Enjoyable Three Floyds approach at a rather boring style.

Surprised at the 92% score, i feel this should be higher. EXCELLENT brew, by far my favorite 3F brew. 22oz bottle poured into stemmed ale glass. Pours an amber color with an inch and a half white head. Beautiful aroma of fruits, citrus and a slight hint of caramel malts. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Flavor almost of peaches, with a nice bitterness that sticks on the palet. Beautiful beer, definitely my favorite 3F brew.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2010 Silly comic drawing on the label.  Medium brown pour.  Sweet, malty aroma with some fragrant English hops (Fuggles, I see).  I can see this has shot up to the top 1% for the style, and I am not surprised.  My first thought was that this is as good an English bitter as I can remember having.  It is better than Fullers, which for some reason is rated higher.  As usual, 3F comes thru with a stellar example of a style.  Mellow and flavorful, with a pleasant tingle and some apple esters.  It is always exciting to try something new from 3F, and this was no exception.

Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Pours a light amber with off-white head. Aroma of piney hops, light caramel and toast. Flavor is very much the same with a nice citrus bite and malty. Mouth feel is medium body with high carbonation. Overall, this was some pretty tasty stuff!

Bomber courtesy of Josh, thanks man.  Pours a clear ruby hued brown with a large creamy soft beige head.  Mouthwatering citrus hops, hints of pineapple and tropical fruit, and a bit of faintly musky malt.  Nice light sweetness with bits of candied citrus peel, lovely toast.  Finishes nice and smooth with a little bit of toast and a good bitterness.  Pretty tasty stuff.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured amber with a white head.  aroma of pine resin and caramel.  flavor was pine and grass with a light body.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11, pours golden orange, aromas of sweet graham cracker and peach, flavors of caramel, piney hops, creamy butter, good finish

UPDATED: APR 9, 2010 22 oz bomber courtesy of Tim.  Thanks a bunch Cuzz !!!  Pours a clear honey amber with a medium sized off white head.  Aroma of honey lemon tea, faint floral hops and light malt.  Taste of honey lemon tea, faint floral notes, light malt and a hint of pine.

Thanks to thirdeye11 for sharing this bottle. I have wanted to try this one for a while and was excited to see it at the tasting. The beer pours an orange, iced tea color with a large white head. The aroma is resiny hops, very impressive for a beer of this style. The flavor is caramel malt along with the same resiny hops from the aroma. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Nose is apricots, wood, and flowers. Taste is tangerines, and caramel. Simple yet tasty.

(22oz bottle via trade with BA gratefulbeerhead) Pours clear amber with light bubbles. Nose of juicy citrus, toasted grains and honeydew. Taste of sweet citrus, earthy, grapefruit and grains. A nicely done ESB.

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  deep amber with a cream head.  big piney hops, grapefruits, and a solid malt backbone.  nice on the palate, piney hop flavor with the big malts coming through in the end.
Well this is a nice little beer.  came out of nowhere with a big hop presence.  This could easily pass for an ipa.   very clean.   refreshing.  solid all around.   would drink again.  tight beer.

Bottle thanks to thirdeye11. Pours with a huge off-white head over a clear brown body. Aroma is really hoppy with light citrus and herbal notes. Taste is nutshells, light lingering bitterness and light hop flavors. Creamy bubbles. Very nice ESB.

Took me forever to find a bottle of this in Chicago.  Pours copper/orange with a nice white head.  Citrus and pine hops in the aroma and flavor with a little bit of caramel.  Well balanced and easy to drink with some nice bitterness.  I like it.

Brown-amber pour with a nice white head. Aroma is both malty and hoppy. Great balance which made this beer extremely drinkable. The malts gave a nice smooth body with excellent hops flavor at the finish.

Pours a golden amber with a small white head. The aroma is pretty hoppy, peppery and floral, with light citrus and some caramel and cereal malt. The flavor is sweet at first, fading into a piney dryness and a peppery, bitter finish. Medium bodied with prickly carbonation. Has a sort of woody finish, but maybe thats just because its really dry. Its no Fullers.

Jons bottle.  The aroma is he irst to hit, amarillo orange like and then some odd acidity.  Beautiful head on cloudy orange. A creamy taste. It is a nice orange IPA bitterness, unique. Lacey. Nice orange aftertaste.

Bomber via trade thanks to dug on BA.

Pours a nice clear amber-brown color with a sticky off-white head and excellent lacing.

Aroma is bright fresh hops, citrusy mostly, slightly herbal, with sweet malt in the background.  Really smells awesome.

Flavor is caramel malt and toffee along with the typical excellent FFF hop character, citrusy, mostly grapefruit, with slight herbal notes as well.  Not terribly much bitterness given the hop aroma and flavor, although its definitely there.

Medium body with some hop resins present on the palate.

Extremely drinkable.  Another great one in FFFs awesome line of hoppy beers.  What an amazing American style English bitter.  Respects the style yet adds a nice twist to it.

$8 bottle from pub. Slightly cheaper elsewhere. [A] This smells like an Alpha king off the bat. Or most any other 3F brew for that matter. Strong juicy citrus, piny tangerine and other tropical fruity quaffs. Hop perfume. Not sure if that is point-worthy anymore. Caramel. Some slight hints of English malt. [A] Pours clear orangish-yellow. The head on the first 1/2 was truly beautiful. Capped until the bottom of the glass. Off-white frothy foam. Excellent retention. Few soapy bubbles. Bottle art kicks ass. [F] - Mouth hits with a strong dose of hops. Mid-body is caramel. Very light bready malt. Fruity with a bitter linger. Not very much depth. Not very "English" to me, either. [P] Bottle served close to cask temperature. Mouth is very thin & hoppy with tingly carbonation. Drinkable. Soft feel, but sharp bite. Not boozy, but astringent enough that you never forget youre drinking a beer. Highly drinkable in the long run. Cask does sound delicious. [O] 55 IBUs come off a bit stronger than posted. Good thing? I must say I am a tad disappointed in this for some reason. But blindly, it was a nice 3F brew. Bitter where it should be, I guess. Just more normal than "not normal" for me. For a 1-off bottling with only 48 ratings, this seemed to fly off the shelves. Wouldnt mind picking one up next year. But if its replaced by another 1-off, I wont complain.

Pours a beautiful amber with a huge white head.  Smells like hops and pineapple, just awesome.  Taste is caramel, with hops all the way down.  Very interesting indeed.  The head does not go away at all.  Lacing is sticking to glass like glue.  This is a great beer to start the night off.  Thanks Sprinkle for this beer man/

Draft @ Three Floyds, Munster,IN. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy aroma with hints of citrus and some hints of caramel. Fruity malty hoppy flavor with citrus and orange hints. Has a fruity malty spicy hoppy finish.

Bomber.  Pours mostly clear, with a dark reddish-amber hue.  A massive column of rocky, ivory tinted froth is excellently retained, and it leaves thick, sticky sheets and splotches of lacing all over the glass.  Distinctly Brittish in composition, with loads of caramelized biscuit and fresh, doughy bread notes, the aroma applies the signature Three Floyds approach in monstrous hopping, showing loads of fresh, juicy grapefruit, bright lemon peel, and peppery grass.  The flavor is just as well constructed, again showing luscious caramel, biscuit, and spiced bread malts that are countered with zesty, bitter grasses and bright grapefruit.  Delicious stuff!  The palate also strikes excellent balance, carrying enough heft and creaminess to satiate the mouth, yet somehow remaining delicate enough to pose as a session brew.  Carbonation is fine and moderate, while the finish shows on the drying side. I could drink this stuff every day and be perfectly happy.  Great beer!  Maybe the best bitter Ive had to date.

Bottle:  Pours a dark amber with a large tan head, significant lacing present.  Immediately the tried-n-true FFFs character comes through on the nose...notes of pineapple and peach along with some slight herbal tones apparent to compliment the sweet bread dough backbone.  Some light caramel and cracker notes as it opens up.  Crisp carbonation, flavors are an amalgam of the aforementioned notes along with a biting, spruce-like finish and a lingering mint leaf note.  Good stuff...wish this was bottled as one of their regulars in 12oz.

Bottle Clear amber/orange ale with a small, creamy, white head. The bouquet is of earthy, musky, pissy hops with an undertone of biscuit malt. Medium-bodied and astringent with lively carbonation. Bursting at the seams with hop flavor  musky, earthy and moderately bitter. A touch of biscuit. Crisp, lightly bitter, dry finish.

Bottle thanks to G-Money. poured copper with nice white head. Aroma was fruity and sweet. Taste was grapefruit with slight piney notes. a very smooth easy to drink and went down very easy. A very enjoyable ESB.

Bottle from stfun...shared with wolf... Nice orange red-ish color, good head. Nice aroma of some sweet grapefuit. Taste is the same... sweet grape fruit hoppy taste. Lots of fruit.  Not sugary... Smooth, medium carbonation. Overall: Nice ESB! Thanks Josh.

Bomber, $6.50.  Hoppy nose is extreeeeemely musty, just loaded up with Fuggles, akin to dank socks that had soaked in orange and grapefruit pulp for a while.  Some pine and spotty resin.  Very effervescent pour throwing off aromatics in every direction, consistent carbonation and a creamy, rocky whitish head atop a beautiful amber body.  Taste is floral, perfumed, resin and pine, hops outpacing the malt.  Malty and dense with an extremely sticky medium body.  Light caramel and lighter earth, some juicy citrus and balanced dry bitterness.  Alcohol well-hidden, just a touch of structure without the taste or warmth.  Intense flavor, too much for a session beer, and no trace of its English origins (an American original, as they say - basically a sticky APA with some Fuggles).  Still in love with that FFF touch, but man, I wish they wouldnt dump in so much Crystal malt, stuff can get fiercely rough.

Bomber. Deep amber, clear body. Large, off-white, frothy head, slowly dminishing. Big hoppy aroma of grapefruit, pine, citrus, toasted grain, flowers and a hint of caramel. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter with a slight alcoholic pepperiness. Medium body, watery texture that turns slightly chewy in the finish, moderate carbonation that is slightly raspy in the aftertaste. Bright, juicy hop taste is long lasting, but the beer is not overly bitter. The nice caramel profile of classic English ESBs is missing here, pretty much run over by the hops. But it still stands on its own as far as being an enjoyable beer.

Bottle from Crown Downtown. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate earthy hop aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy spicy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.

coppery color, fluffy white head, lacy.  nose of floral hops and malt.  malt and dried fruit in the flavor, followed by a bitter hop taste.  medium bodied, nice bitter finish.  i enjoyed this one on tap @ three floyds brewpub.
Super clean, piney, floral hop aroma.  More crisp hops in the flavor, balanced perfectly with a light sweetness.

Bomber from Binnys Des Plaines. Pours clear amber with 2 finger white head with good lacing. Nose is loaded with hops, grapefruit, tropical fruits and some light caramel and light malt. Flavors of caramel, toffee, citrus, mango, malt, and bitter hops. Finishes with bitter hops. Wonderful hoppy aroma. Solid malt backbone to balance out all the hops. By far the hoppiest ESB I have had, which is not surprise given the brewery. Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber with a thick white head that lasts and laces quite nicely. Aroma has notes of resin and pine with a bit of an undertone of grains. The hops give a nice bitter pine flavor with an undertone of smooth grains and cereal. Strong beer.

22oz bottle.  Pours a clear glowing rich bright amber with a nice dense white froth.  Aroma of amarillo, hint of banana, very fresh and nicely balanced.  Strong juicy hop flavor, citrus, tea bitterness, malt flour, long lasting bitter finish/aftertaste, touch of banana/bubble-gum, hint of nuttiness, medium/strong sweet, a nice hybrid.  Medium bodied, chalky on the finish, malt flour, great ESB aftertaste.

Huge head sits atop a clear,light,amber beer. Potent floral,fruity,hop aromas pretty much dominate the underlying malty aromas,which in this case isnt a bad thing. Little caramel,bread. Medium texture,and body. Very smooth,and clean. Upfront bready,caramel,malt flavors are overpowered by the floral,pine,hops. Hops just sit on the tounge. FInish is more florals,and tropical fruit lingering with bready malts. Very clean,tasty, and more fresh than anything Ive had from them in some time.This is not a European style ESB,but I do like.

Bottle by way of StFun  thanks again Josh!  Pours a highly carbonated amber with a 2 finger foamy off-white head that leaves coating lacing.  The nose is fresh citrus, malt and pine.  The taste is apricots, citrus, caramel malt and a light grapefruity finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  Highly drinkable stuff  thanks Big J!

First bottling, picked up at Kahns. Pours crystal clear amber/brown with minimal white head. Nose is FFF hops with citrus/grapefruit going on. Flavor is sharp, dry, bitter, characteristic of ESB but with a nicely balanced twist of lemon, peach, mango hops.  Definitely not my favorite style by far, but MAJOR kudos to FFF for making this drinkable through the use of their trademark hopping style.

I like bitter!  Nice brew - I dont have enough experience rating ESBs as a style, but this seemed much like an American IPA. Piney and citrus nose and flavor. I did pick up notes of caramel. Great hop flavor. Nice caramel color and good frothy head with lacing. This is a very drinkable, enjoyable beer.

Bottle.  Pour is clear deep brown with a beige head.  Aroma is resin and pine hops with rich caramel malt and a lightly metallic aroma.  Flavor is resin and citrus hops with a caramel malt backbone.  Its tasty and well balanced.

StLHops tasting.  Whiskey appearance.  Not a big aroma but hops are prominent along with some fruit.  Flavor is huge biting hops that are incredibly intense.  The beer warms and brings some caramel and grapes.  Also some very welcome smoothness.  Hop heads will love this one but it was too intense for my tastes.

aroma of strong pine, flavor is dry with grapefruit, pine and resin.  deep amber piour with reducing head and great lacing.  ultra drinkable beer that provides my hop fix but far too brash to be any kind of ESB, good or bad.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2010 11/2/2008: Pint at the brew pub. Really great, creamy bitter aroma. Flavor is pretty great: lots of great bitter hops balances with the caramel malts. Mouthfeel was creamy, and, overall, this is an excellent ESB.

Re-rate: 1/23/10.  22 oz bottle from the brewery.  This is a stoundout ESB.  The head stays atop this thing forever.  Cookie dough malts mixed with flavorful hops.  Perfect creamy texture.  Bumped it up a couple points.

This version seemed like a cross between an ESB and an American IPA. The aroma is very citusy, though the yeast gives the beer a smoother palate than an IPA. All around it’s a pretty good beer, just not what I expect from an ESB.

Imperial Pint on tap at the Brewpub. 6 Words: One of the Best ESBs Ever. Maybe its the super floral bouquet, or maybe the abundance of hops. But this brew nearly tops all other ESBs Ive had. The malt bill is a little light, therefore the balance doesnt necessarily win points, but how can you pour enough malty sweetness into a brew with such a deep, abiding hoppiness. Maybe it is the IPA fan in me, but this one and the Brutal are neck and neck, and are both extremely different. Dark amber body with a decent offwhite / tannish head. Aromas are a wonderous floral bouquet coupled with a lighter malty sweetness. The hoppy nose steals the show with this beer. Head laces well. Taste is similar, large hoppiness up front, moving to a small malt bill sweetness, moving again to a bitter, but smooth finish. Remarkable. Cheers!
A nice ESB.  For me the ESB standard is Anvil, but this was even slightly smoother.  The expected downside was an absence of the characteristic caramel notes, but pleasant nonetheless.

On tap @ 3F for Andrews Bachelor Party.  Pours orange with a clear beige head.  Light hops and carmel in the nose.  Orange citrus with a light sweet creaminess.  Some spicy/noble hops from underneath the malt.  Tasty for the style.  I dont think it deserved first at NotLA, but Im happy to try it again.

Tap at Spuyten Duyvil.  Deep amber with a thick off-white head that lasts and lasts.  Great fresh tangerine citrus notes right away but there is also a lovely earthy, crackery UK-type maltiness in back.  Bread crust and light caramel.  While the hops are the first thing that you notice with this beer, the attention to the malts really sell it.  There is lots of hop aroma and flavour, but the bitterness is quite restrained.  Soft caramel integrates nicely with the sweet malts.  Earthy hop finish in spite of all of the citrus up front.  One of the first US-style bitters Ive had that really lives up the character of the style.
Rather dark amber pour...releasing a pretty potent aroma of American hops... pine resiny and a bit catty.  big caramely/biscuity maltiness to sweeten it up. This is very sessionable.
On tap at 3F during RBSG Road Trip 2007. Slightly hazy brown with an off white head. Nice lace. Very citrusy nose, somewhat tannic. Flavor more relaxed, citrusy but with a nutty malt balance.
On tap at the brewpub.  Red-brown with small white head.  Piney, grain aroma.  Pine, sweet substantial malt, and cherry flavor. Full-med body.  Very nice ESB.

Tap at brewery: Rich coppery hue with golden highlight, small lasting head and okay lace. The aroma has notes of pale and biscuity malt, floral grassy and slightly piney hops,  light citric notes, and an earthy quality to the nose. The taste starts mildly malty before a rush of hop bitterness comes forth. Sort of a hybrid with equal part classic hop and an Americanized piney overtone. Even a bit nutty at some point. Finished with some metallic notes and mostly dry on the aftertaste. An easy drinker but larger than a normal session brew. Not your standard ESB, more akin to an APA, tasty never the less.

On tap at the brewpub. Slightly hazy copper body with a large creamy off-white head. Strong sweet citrus hops aroma with a tea-like maltiness in the background. Sweet citrus and grassy hops flavor with some light caramel. Very easy to drink.
draft at brewpub: clear amber, aroma is floral with grapefruit. Medium bodied with moderate bitterness and of course the 3F softness. Enjoyable.

Chicago trip. Saturday 15:45. On tap at the brewery. Ordered because I like the style. 3/4" head in a pint glass. Very dark amber/light copper. Hop nose with backing caramel. Grapefruit hops and toffee flavours. Hoppy but not a Fullers ESB. Hops push back the malts.

Draught.  At the brewpub.  Dropped in on my way to Chicago.  Poured hazy amber with a decent head.  Aroma is a little up-front hoppy for an ESB, but green and nicely pungent - a little sweet, nicely herbal - had fresh euro pils character.  Nice malt/light funk fresh hop flavour, nice, reminds me a lot of their "mild" ale - very drinkable.  Average body, good carbonation, lightly bitter - very good!

On tap a FFF.  Pours a deep red/amber with a nice tan fluffy head.  Head diminishes quickly.  Leaves a nice lacing.  Aroma is of lighly sweet fruity dry hops.  Flavor is all sweet hops with sublte notes of caramel and fruit.  Medium creamy body with a lightly bitter finish.  This beer is excellent.  Very smooth.  A nice surprise!

On tap at 3F.  Poured a clear, deeper amber with 1" of creamy off-white head.. sticky lacing followed it down.  The aroma found soft caramel with heavy floral hoppage.. some pineapple too.. sweet and alluring.  Flavor was of a hella-hopped bitter... soft caramel, toffee, and light fruity sweetness (peach, pineapple, and mango) base with a juicy bitterness surrounding... lingering floral and fruity bitterness at the finish.  Medium-bodied.. smooth, sweeter base was well-balanced with all the bitterness around it.  Good stuff!

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2010 draft at 3F.....eh is all i can say about this one....appearanceL looks like a fizzy apple juice with a thin white head...hoppy nose.....tasted like a really subdued american pale ale.  not my cup of tea and i wish i had more to say about this one.....an average beer all-around. nice citrusy and floral hop profile. Lots better than when I had it last. Soft carbonation.
a mighty refreshing pint. An Americanized ESB, full of some tasty american hops. yum!

Imperial pint draft at Floyds. British? Hah! Despite assurances its got all British ale hops, its still at the usual 3Fs strength: a rush of lime, pineapple, pine tree and cat box. A lovely brown English beer color, though, just a bit hazy with a light scrum of foam. Hop hit is cheek by jowl to a hearty English malt bill, sweet and chewy as a fresh baked cookie. Nelsons body could have preferred to be shipped home in a barrel of this, instead of French brandy!"Kiss me, Hardy!"

On tap at brewpub,a dark amber looking beer similar to alpha king but not as hoppy.This was a very smooth and tasty beer that won an  award for its style .I give nick and the guys a big CHEERS for trying something a little different and it won them first place.CHEERS!

Theres a noticable viscosity to a light-hazed amber body under a sudsy head. Sharp, peppery grapefruit in the nose with a touch of dishwater if I inhale too deeply. An IPA with that English tilt, hops get balanced but still shine with a strong peppery punch. An award winner tonight, and deservedly so.

NotLA3.  i really liked this.  definitely didnt think it was an ESB... awesome beer, really took to the cask well.  really hoppy, but not traditional west coast hops.  citrusy without being real sharp.  the flavor wasnt as hoppy and was quite well balanced.

Well,  I wont bash this like everyone else did.  I actually voted this at 3rd place.  its true, it was very hoppy.  im surprised they got such a citrusy aroma from fuggles.  it was a little watery but it was good.  Im surprised thats its listed as an ESB. seemed like an IPAto me.

At Night of the Living Ales (Chicago, IL)  There were a lot of hoppy ales that night...too many.  I need variety.  This hoppy ale was different.  Obviously different enough and well made enough to be the peoples favorite.  It had a tremendous hop smell.  The taste was pure grapefruit.  If you want that in a beer, this is for you.  Nice enough to sample but not one that Id drink a whole lot of...and Im a 3 Floyds fan.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2007 It has a copper/amber body with a bubbly white head.  Nice malt aroma with a floral/herbal hopping.  A bit thin, but had decent enough malty flavors with a suggestion of fruit.  What I liked was the hops (Hops?  From 3F?) that grew in the flavor and left a refreshingly bitter finish. UPDATED: JUL 15, 2007 on tap at the brewery. pours coppery with off white head. nose is hoppy with biscuit. flavor is wonderfully well balanced with hops and malt, biscuit. extremely sessionable. body is thin to medium. i could drink this all day.
